channel.title: NPR Programs: Morning Edition
channel.description: Morning Edition takes listeners around the country and the world with multi-faceted stories and commentaries every weekday. Hosts Steve Inskeep, Leila Fadel, Michel Martin and A Martínez bring you the latest breaking news and features to prepare you for the day.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Government shutdown enters its second week
item.description: The government shutdown is entering its second week, and there's no end in sight as both parties continue to refuse to give in to the other's demands.
item.content:encoded: The government shutdown is entering its second week, and there's no end in sight as both parties continue to refuse to give in to the other's demands.
item.dc:creator: Domenico Montanaro

item.title: Shutdowns serve as excuse for GOP and Democrats to spend more, says Sen. Ron Johnson
item.description: Sen. Ron Johnson, a Republican from Wisconsin, has a plan for how to avoid shutdown showdown negotiations, but it wouldn't be popular with Congress' "uniparty," he told NPR.
item.content:encoded:
Sen. Ron Johnson, a Republican from Wisconsin, has a plan for how to avoid shutdown showdown negotiations, but it wouldn't be popular with Congress' "uniparty," he told NPR.

(Image credit: J. Scott Applewhite)
item.dc:creator: Obed Manuel

item.title: Morning news brief
item.description: The government shutdown enters its second week, FAA staffing shortages caused by the shutdown delay flights across the country, former FBI Director James Comey will be arraigned Wednesday.
item.content:encoded: The government shutdown enters its second week, FAA staffing shortages caused by the shutdown delay flights across the country, former FBI Director James Comey will be arraigned Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: A Martínez

item.title: Israel cites security, but Palestinians say West Bank gates disrupt daily life
item.description: In the last two years Israel has erected hundreds of gates to restrict the movement of Palestinians in the occupied West Bank, making daily life more difficult for residents there.
item.content:encoded: In the last two years Israel has erected hundreds of gates to restrict the movement of Palestinians in the occupied West Bank, making daily life more difficult for residents there.
item.dc:creator: Carrie Kahn

item.title: Research shows a simple strategy can protect babies from malaria-carrying mosquitoes
item.description: In sub-Saharan Africa, a child under five dies nearly every minute from malaria. But new research suggests baby wraps treated with insect repellant can protect them.
item.content:encoded: In sub-Saharan Africa, a child under five dies nearly every minute from malaria. But new research suggests baby wraps treated with insect repellant can protect them.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Lambert

item.title: Former FBI Director Jim Comey to be arraigned on criminal charges
item.description: A day after Attorney General Pam Bondi was questioned about whether the Justice Department is being weaponized, former FBI Director Jim Comey will be arraigned on criminal charges.
item.content:encoded: A day after Attorney General Pam Bondi was questioned about whether the Justice Department is being weaponized, former FBI Director Jim Comey will be arraigned on criminal charges.
item.dc:creator: Carrie Johnson

item.title: 'I was so stunned': Brokers for North Korean defectors investigated for espionage
item.description: Many North Korean defectors in South Korea use a secret network of brokers to stay connected to those back home. But recently, South Korea investigated some of those brokers for espionage.
item.content:encoded: Many North Korean defectors in South Korea use a secret network of brokers to stay connected to those back home. But recently, South Korea investigated some of those brokers for espionage.
item.dc:creator: Se Eun Gong

item.title: Study finds workplace injuries increase significantly in the heat
item.description: As the Occupational Safety and Health Administration considers new rules that would protect American workers from the heat, a new study found they could help prevent some 28,000 injuries a year.
item.content:encoded: As the Occupational Safety and Health Administration considers new rules that would protect American workers from the heat, a new study found they could help prevent some 28,000 injuries a year.
item.dc:creator: Alejandra Borunda

item.title: Air traffic control staffing shortages causing flight delays across the U.S.
item.description: An increasing number of air traffic control facilities in the U.S. have had to reduce the number of planes they can handle in their airspace since the government shutdown began.
item.content:encoded: An increasing number of air traffic control facilities in the U.S. have had to reduce the number of planes they can handle in their airspace since the government shutdown began.
item.dc:creator: Joel Rose

item.title: The Root returns to Black ownership. Here's how Ashley Allison is reimagining it
item.description: NPR's Michel Martin speaks with Ashley Allison, the new owner of the online media outlet "The Root," which focuses on covering Black news and opinion.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Michel Martin speaks with Ashley Allison, the new owner of the online media outlet "The Root," which focuses on covering Black news and opinion.
item.dc:creator: Michel Martin
